messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: My Mito tsuba followup
messages.msgSnippet: ... Thanks Jim and Rich.  As for your above comments, I think I have firmly established what I like.  Seperate from these discussed pieces, I am seeking out
messages.messageBody:
> IMHO the school doesn't matter as long as you like
> them.
> (Collect what you like, but like what you collect
> :-)
>
> Rich S
>

Thanks Jim and Rich. As for your above comments, I
think I have firmly established what I like. Seperate
from these discussed pieces, I am seeking out various
other schools from the Mito Shoami type to have a
representation of all the schools that used the mantis
in their work. My humble collection of 12 tsuba is
growing with representation of both kinko and sukashi.
I really would love to put out a book one day on just
mantis fittings. Whoever owns that tsuba on the
Northern California site please feel free to leave
that to me in my will. Given that however, I do like
these Mito tsuba and kinda like the idea of having a
potential dai-sho for mounting or at least 1 for
display and 1 for mounting. Thanks again.
Ken

__________________________________

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: My Mito tsuba followup
messages.msgSnippet: I sent this earlier, but it hasn t posted.  No doubt it will any moment now... ... Ken, There are signed Aizu Shoami tsuba.  Some of them are fairly good
messages.messageBody:
I sent this earlier, but it hasn't posted. No doubt it will any moment now...
--------------------------
Ken,
There are signed Aizu Shoami tsuba. Some of them are fairly good quality, and others are pretty poor. It's certainly possible that the "Mito" shiiremono tsuba could be made by Aizu workers, but the workmanship is a bit different from even the low end signed Aizu work. We're probably not going to find any signed shiiremono examples to settle the issue. I think that Aizu Shoami is a better label than Mito Shoami, since we do have documented Shoami makers in Aizu (but not in Mito), but I'm not sure it's correct. Ultimately, they're copying the Nara style.

Jim

Hi all,

I made one little error in my reporting, I thought the
one being auctioned was the same as I saw on the
website, but it is different. This is the one I am
referring to in the response as Aizu Shoami which
exactly matches my smaller one pictured (which bye the
way isn't small at all).

http://www.finesword.co.jp/sale/k081.htm

The other one pictured on yahoo japan does look more
like my larger one sans the shakudo mimi and plugs
which all agree is Mito. It is this one above and its
brother in my possesion that Jim G said was possibley
Mito Shoami, but the gentleman at finesword said was
Aizu Shoami. I'm hoping that I can get the yahoo
japan one cheaply with our cowboy's help. It is kind
of a cross between the 2. While it does look like
they are done by the same hand, it is still possible
that the Aizu were copying the Mito? Aren't they near
each other location wise ie Northern Japan? Kind of
funny how these all appeared and got me salivating.

Thanks.
Ken



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: My Mito tsuba followup
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, High end Mito work is in an entirely different universe from the best Aizu Shoami.  It s not really my taste, but the good Mito makers were highly
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
High end Mito work is in an entirely different universe from the best Aizu Shoami. It's not really my taste, but the good Mito makers were highly skilled kinko.

Jim



Ken -

The styles of Aizu Shoami and Mito are very similar IMHO.
Although I think the better, high end Mito work is a bit
superior. Both schools did a lot of copying of other
schools (Nara especially) work. Both schools produced
tons of shiriimono, but also some nice pieces. I like
the ones you've shown and hope you are able to get them.
IMHO the school doesn't matter as long as you like them.
(Collect what you like, but like what you collect :-)

Rich S

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: My Mito tsuba followup
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, That type of workmanship and tagane-mei are typical of the type of Nara-copy shiiremono tsuba that Bob Haynes called Mito Shoami in his auction
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
That type of workmanship and tagane-mei are typical of the type of Nara-copy shiiremono tsuba that Bob Haynes called "Mito Shoami" in his auction catalogs. I just flipped through the tsuba section of "Tetsu no Isho, Mito-to to Tosogu no Meihin," and I don't see that tagane-mei on any of the Mito tsuba there. The workmanship of the two tsuba with the tagane marks looks a lot like that of the two mokko Shoami tsuba lower on the same page.

Jim



Ken -

IMHO, no doubt yours and the Japanese auction one are Mito.
The tagane-mei are very characteristic of Mito work. The
pattern on your small tsuba, the Japanese one and two on
my tsuba page (top center, top right)

http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/tsuba/tsubapic.htm

are the same. The work just screams Mito IMHO.

Rich S


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: [nihontostudy] "Samurai" for US Cable Subscribers
messages.msgSnippet: News Release: “Samurai” a 2-hour special program on the Samurai warrior will debut on the History Channel on December 8, from 9:00-11:00pm and again on
messages.messageBody:
News Release:

�Samurai� a 2-hour special program on the Samurai warrior
will debut on the History Channel on December 8, from 9:00-11:00pm and
again on December 9 from 1:00-3:00am and on December 13, from
10:00-12:00pm. Please check your local listings for airing times or go to
historychannel.com. for more details.

According to the History Channel
press release:
The knights of medieval Japan, the Samurai held power for
over 700 years. Ferocious in combat, these masters of sword and bow were
bound by an unforgiving code of ethics. Their legacy of martial artistry,
ceremony, self-discipline, and tenacity persists. Explore the history and
mystery of this elite warrior class as present-day Samurai demonstrate
their ancient skills in this 2-hour special, and historians and experts
examine the meaning and ritual of Bushido--the way of the warrior. TV PG


The program will feature an interview with Rev. Kensho Furuya, Chief
Instructor of the Aikido Center of Los Angeles, in Little Tokyo, and noted
author, historian and expert on the Samurai sword.

messages.subject: My Mito tsuba followup
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, You all may recall a few months ago the 2 tsuba that I had emailed about which started the whole Mito Shoami does it exist or not thread.  I came
messages.messageBody:
Hi all,

You all may recall a few months ago the 2 tsuba that I
had emailed about which started the whole Mito Shoami
does it exist or not thread. I came across this last
week on a website and it is now listed on yahoojapan
auction.
http://page7.auctions.yahoo.co.jp/jp/auction/g11105190

Jim G said he would have attributed the larger to Mito
while the smaller to Mito Shoami. (Here is the link
for my mantis folder in the other yahoo group list
photo area) to see the ones I am talking about
http://photos.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihonto/vwp?.dir=/mantis&.src=gr&.dnm=tsuba+11+%26+1.jpg&.view=t&.done=http%3a//photos.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihonto/lst%3f%26.dir=/mantis%26.src=gr%26.view=t

I emailed the seller of this new being auctioned and
this was his response: "The 081 Tsuba was made in the
last of edo period, 19 century. And the school of
tsuba is presumed Aizu Shoami made. There is
comparatively cheap in comparison with the quality."

Perhaps those items we are attributing to Mito Shoami
are done by Aizu Shoami? I know they did a lot of
mass produced, but even with that I think I read that
they did have competant metal workers? Any comments
on these Aizu? Perhaps they were copying the Mito in
this particular case?

Thanks.
Ken

P.S. This one being auctioned really is tying the ones
I own together even more. Dai-sho in the making!

__________________________________
